newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel, PLO remove main obstacle to Hebron deal.
newsitem.headline: Israel, PLO remove main obstacle to Hebron deal.

text.p: Israel and the PLO have removed the main obstacle to a deal on the West Bank town of Hebron, Israeli and Palestinian officials said after a lightning mediation mission to Gaza and Tel Aviv by Jordan's King Hussein.
Both sides agreed on Sunday to compromise on mid-1998 for the completion of three Israeli troop withdrawals from mostly rural areas of the West Bank, the officials said.

A timeframe for the pullbacks, originally scheduled to be completed by September this year, has been the main stumbling block to sealing a deal on implementing a long overdue Israeli troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.

"King Hussein, U.S. envoy Dennis Ross and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu telephoned Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and told him Netanyahu has accepted the formula," said a PLO official who asked not to be identified.

"I think because of the important initiative that His Majesty took we have made considerable progress and I think we can envision the end of the negotiations in sight," Netanyahu said after meeting the monarch late on Sunday.

Israeli and Palestinians negotiators planned to meet in Jerusalem on Monday to work out the final details and a summit between Netanyahu and Arafat could be held within 48 hours, officials from both sides said.

The PLO had been reluctant to sign an accord on Hebron, where some 400 Jewish settlers live amid more than 100,000 Palestinians, without a commitment from Israel to carry out the additional West Bank pullbacks agreed in previous peace deals.

Israel had proposed to complete the West Bank pullbacks by May 1999 and the United States has suggested mid-1998. The PLO had demanded Israel stick to a peace deal under which the withdrawals were to have been completed by September this year.
King Hussein discussed the mid-1998 compromise during talks earlier on Sunday in Gaza with Arafat and by telephone with Egyptian leader Hosni Mubarak. The king then flew to Tel Aviv to see Netanyahu.
"I think there was significant progress on the subjects that are not connected with Hebron," Netanyahu said in a clear reference to the three West Bank pullbacks.
"As you know, the Hebron agreement is effectively complete and this evening, I think with the important help of King Hussein, we have made another advance," Netanyahu told a news conference.
"There are still details which we have to care of. With the help and goodwill of all the sides, Jordan and Egypt, I believe we can complete the negotiations," he said.
A PLO official said Israel and the Palestinians had agreed to start the first of the three West Bank rural redeployments on February 28.

King Hussein told the Tel Aviv news conference: "I believe...we are on the verge of the completion of a long road and as far as I'm concerned, I leave here confident that everything will move in the right direction."

U.S. envoy Dennis Ross, who had planned to return home on Sunday after the latest three-week round of talks, said President Bill Clinton had asked him to remain in the region "because of the progress that was made today".
